newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan president OKs tax plan to boost investment.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan president OKs tax plan to boost investment.

text.p: Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui has approved the Finance Ministry's "two-into-one" tax merger plan to boost the island's investment and economy, which has been slowing in recent quarters, officials said on Thursday.
"President Lee said the tax proposal is feasible," a Government Information Office official said by telephone.
Premier Lien Chan and several ministers met with President Lee on Wednesday, the official said.
Officials also quoted President Lee as saying he hoped the proposal will be effective from January 1, 1998.

A Finance Ministry official said: "Officials who attended the meeting said President Lee directed that the proposal should be effective from January 1, 1998, and demanded the Finance Ministry to have good communications with parliament."
The proposal needs a final approval by parliament.
Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on October 9 that the ministry would merge the island's two income taxes into one business income tax and set the merged rate at 25 percent.
The move would reduce tax revenues by about T$26.8 billion (US$975 million) a year, Chiu said.
But the ministry would recoup the losses by assessing a 10 percent levy on profits that enterprises reserve rather than distribute to shareholders immediately, he said.
The new tax system would avoid double taxation and would help corporate structures, Chiu said.
"In fact this is a tax reduction," Chiu said. "It will encourage investment (in Taiwan) and increase our international competitiveness."

Taiwan has been trying to woo the Asia-Pacific operations of major multinationals by boosting local economic competitiveness, but has been hobbled by the slow pace of promised market liberalisation, including tax reform.
Foreign nationals' taxes were not affected because their maximum rate would remain the same at 40 percent, Chiu said.
The "two-into-one" tax merger is an accounting change that eliminates double taxation of companies' profits and the dividends they pay to shareholders.
Maximum assessments on domestic individuals' income will be capped at 40 percent, compared with a maximum of 55 percent before the merger.
Currently, foreign investors' income is taxed first by a 25 percent business income tax, and then a 20 percent dividend tax on the 75 percent untaxed portion, making the rate at 40 percent.
Economists said the tax reform would encourge domestic investment, but not on foreign investment.
"We don't see any improvement on how to encourge foreign investment in the proposal," said Sun Ke-nan, a panel memeber from the Chunghua Institution for Economic Research.
"In order to develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific operation centre, we may consider lowering the dividend tax on foreign investors to 15 percent from the current 20 percent," Sun said.
-- Taipei Newsroom (5080815)
